norbertr 0.0.1

    • Some Tools for Understanding Drift Diffusion Models
    • Bayesian inference of a drift diffusion model

    Bayesian inference of a drift diffusion model

    stan_demo.Rmd

    Here’s a Stan model for inferring the relative starting point, drift rate and inter-barrier distance of the drift diffusion model. This assumes those three values are fixed, though unknown. In other words, those values do not vary with predictor variables. In practice, of course, we want these parameters to vary with predictors as in a typical regression model. This model is intended as just a simple demo of inference in a non-regression model drift diffusion model.

    data {
  int<lower=1> n;
  real<lower=0> y[n];
  int<lower=0, upper=1> z[n];
  real<lower=0> alpha_ub;
  real<lower=0> sigma;
  real<lower=0> tau;
}

parameters {
  real<lower=0, upper=alpha_ub> alpha;
  real<lower=0, upper=1> beta;
  real delta;
}

model {

  // priors
  alpha ~ uniform(0, alpha_ub);
  beta ~ uniform(0, 1);
  delta ~ normal(0, sigma);

  // likelihood model
  for (i in 1:n) {

    if (z[i] == 1){
      // upper barrier crossing times
      y[i] ~ wiener(alpha, tau, beta, delta);
    } else {
      // lower barrier crossing times
      y[i] ~ wiener(alpha, tau, 1-beta, -delta);
    }

  }

}

    This model is called by norbertr::ddm_stan. Here it is in practice.

    library(norbertr)
library(tidyverse)

set.seed(10101)

sims_df <- simulate_ddm(1000, b = 0.75, a = 2, v = 0.5) %>%
  dplyr::mutate(time = time + 0.1)

M <- ddm_stan(time + choice ~ 1, data = sims_df, cores = 4)

    And the results:

    M
#> Inference for Stan model: ddm.
#> 4 chains, each with iter=2000; warmup=1000; thin=1; 
#> post-warmup draws per chain=1000, total post-warmup draws=4000.
#> 
#>          mean se_mean   sd    2.5%     25%     50%     75%   97.5% n_eff Rhat

#> beta     0.74    0.00 0.01    0.73    0.74    0.74    0.75    0.76  1755    1
#> delta    0.47    0.00 0.05    0.38    0.43    0.47    0.50    0.56  1759    1
#> lp__  -705.94    0.03 1.28 -709.17 -706.50 -705.62 -705.03 -704.50  1784    1
#>

#> and Rhat is the potential scale reduction factor on split chains (at 
#> convergence, Rhat=1).
